Journal.Title: Journal of stomatology, oral and maxillofacial surgery

Article.ArticleTitle: Effect of ozone therapy on the modulation of inflammation and on new bone formation in critical defects of rat calvaria filled with autogenous graft.

AbstractText: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of ozone therapy on new bone formation and inflammation modulation in defects of rat calvaria filled with autogenous bone.

Critical size defects were created in the calvaria of 24 male Wistar rats. The animals were randomly divided into four groups according to the treatment: G1: clot; G2: clot and covered with xenogenic membrane; G3: particulate autogenous bone graft; G4: autogenous bone graft and application of 3 mL O<sub>2</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> gas mixture (10 µg/ml). The defects were filled immediately after surgery with a bilateral retroauricular application, in the region immediately above the incision. After 21 days, the animals were euthanized, and the samples were processed for morphometric evaluations designed to measure both the intensity of the inflammatory infiltrate, and the presence of new bone formation in the defect.

The results showed a lower inflammation score and higher mean of newly formed bone in the region of the defect for the group associated with ozone therapy (G4). The bone formed in the region of the defect could be observed as being more lamellar and mineralized in the case of associated ozone therapy.
Ozone therapy represents a promising adjuvant therapy to accelerate tissue regeneration.
